On Thu, 19 Aug 2004 09:28:23 -0700, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> After almost 7 thousand generations, the champion topology only had 2 hidden
> nodes.  One had two connections, one had about 10.  At this rate, I'll be
> old and gray before it gets anywhere.
> 
> Any ideas how to speed up the process of adding topology without losing the
> ability to optimize and thoroughly evaluate those topologies?

This is probably a result of putting every distinct topology in a
seperate species.

I was wondering how, after finding out the way NEAT actually handles
mutations, topologies ever complexified significantly.  If an add node
connection mutation rate of 0.01 with a population of 100 means that
an average of one node will be added in the entire population in one
generation, it seemed like a painfully slow way of incrementing
topology.  It seems the answer is crossover.  Even if through mutation
only one node is added in the first generation, if there is only one
species and that individual is mating with other individuals without
that node, then presumably there could be 30 extra nodes in the
subsequent generation.

If topology is not cumulative due to the effects of crossover in this
way, mutation will be the only way to increment topology, and you're
not exploiting the effects of crossover.  So on average, if your
mutation rates are 0.01 for add node and 0.03 for add connection, with
a population size of 100 evolved for 100 generations, your average
individual will accumulate 1 new node and 3 new connections, which is
about on par with what you're experiencing.

So it seems to me you're either going to need to use crossover, as
NEAT does.  Or dramatically increase your mutation rates.

Derek
